docs.snippet: The National Book Critics Circle last night gave its prize for fiction to ''Austerlitz,'' by W. G. Sebald, a dreamlike meditation on memory and the Holocaust, published by Random House. Mr. Sebald died in December at 57, in a car accident near his...
docs.lead_paragraph: The National Book Critics Circle last night gave its prize for fiction to ''Austerlitz,'' by W. G. Sebald, a dreamlike meditation on memory and the Holocaust, published by Random House. Mr. Sebald died in December at 57, in a car accident near his home in Norwich, England. The award for general nonfiction went to Nicholson Baker, for ''Double Fold: Libraries and the Assault on Paper'' (Random House), about the disappearance of the knowledge in library books and other paper materials that are being discarded for lack of storage space.
docs.abstract: National Book Critics Circle announces awards: fiction prize to W G Sebald for Austerlitz, general nonfiction prize to Nicholson Baker for Double Fold, poetry prize to Albert Goldbarth for Saving Lives, biography prize to Adam Sisman for Boswell's Presumptuous Task, criticism prize of Martin Amis for The War Against Cliche, Nona Balakian Citation for Excellence in Reviewing to Michael Gorra, and Ivan Sandrof Lifetime Achievement Award to the editor Jason Epstein (S)

docs.snippet: Serbia handed over 145 ethnic Albanian prisoners from the Kosovo war to United Nations officials in Kosovo, meeting an American demand. Most were accused of terrorism and murder during the 1998-99 war, in which Serbian forces fought ethnic Albania...
docs.lead_paragraph: Serbia handed over 145 ethnic Albanian prisoners from the Kosovo war to United Nations officials in Kosovo, meeting an American demand. Most were accused of terrorism and murder during the 1998-99 war, in which Serbian forces fought ethnic Albanian guerrillas. The United States Congress had made the transfer by March 31 a condition for $40 million in aid. The prisoners will serve out their sentences in Kosovo, which is under United Nations administration, while Serbian prisoners held in Kosovo will be sent to jails elsewhere in Serbia.
docs.abstract: Serbia hands over 145 ethnic Albanian prisoners to UN officials in Kovoso; photo (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Serbs Return Prisoners

docs.snippet: While the world's attention has been focused on the living conditions and legal status of Qaeda suspects in Guantánamo Bay, a much larger group of Taliban prisoners in Afghanistan is at risk of dying in detention. Some 3,500 Afghan and Pakistani ...
docs.lead_paragraph: While the world's attention has been focused on the living conditions and legal status of Qaeda suspects in Guantánamo Bay, a much larger group of Taliban prisoners in Afghanistan is at risk of dying in detention. Some 3,500 Afghan and Pakistani Taliban men are being held in dangerously squalid conditions in the Shebarghan prison in northern Afghanistan. In our visit to the prison on Jan. 20, we found cell blocks designed for 20 prisoners holding up to 100 men; 8 to 10 toilets for each 1,000 men; bathing facilities outdoors in the mud; and grossly inadequate food and medical care. Dysentery is epidemic. The prison's commander, General Jarobak, told us that ''many, many, many men'' had already died. The American military knows about these conditions and has a duty under international law to ensure that the prisoners are treated humanely. This obligation falls on both the Afghan government and the United States, which led the war in Afghanistan. Regardless of whether the United States captured these prisoners or has actual custody of them, it shares with the Afghan government responsibility for their decent care.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Jennifer Learning and John Heffernan of Physicians for Human Rights reoprts that some 3,500 Afghan and Pakistani Taliban men are being held in dangerously squalid conditions in Shebarghan prison in northern Afghanistan, where they are at risk of dying in detention (M)

byline.original: By Jennifer Leaning and John Heffernan

docs.snippet: A global survey has found that that the number of serious international conflicts diminished this year.    Of 193 countries evaluated by the National Defense Council Foundation, 59 have had serious conflicts this year, from separatist-ethnic viole...
docs.lead_paragraph: A global survey has found that that the number of serious international conflicts diminished this year. Of 193 countries evaluated by the National Defense Council Foundation, 59 have had serious conflicts this year, from separatist-ethnic violence and political fighting to drug trafficking, religious turmoil and a mutiny.
docs.abstract: National Defense Council Foundation reports that number of serious international conflicts diminished in 2001, to 59 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a co-screenwriter of the film ''Harrison's Flowers,'' and author of the autobiography ''Le Diable a l'avantage'' from which the movie was adapted, I would like to respond to issues raised by Stephen Kinzer in his article ''A Story the Movies Can't Get Right'' [March 3].
docs.abstract: Harrison's Flowers' co-screenwriter Isabel Ellsen letter responds to issues raised by Stephen Kinzer's March 3 article about press photographers' actions in war zones

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    For our government to sell documents on how to create germ weapons that our foreign and domestic enemies can use against us is certainly a recipe for disaster (front page, Jan. 13). Anyone can find out how to make anthrax and oth...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: For our government to sell documents on how to create germ weapons that our foreign and domestic enemies can use against us is certainly a recipe for disaster (front page, Jan. 13). Anyone can find out how to make anthrax and other lethal germs for just $15. This is where our freedom of speech needs some fine-tuning. If we cannot yell ''fire!'' in a crowded theater because it will endanger others, then recipes for germ warfare should certainly be reclassified.
docs.abstract: Kathryn Gandal calls for some fine-tuning of freedom of speech if it means documents on making germ weapons are freely available to those who would kill Americans (S)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Saying Battle Is Reaching End, U.S. Sends Troops Back to Base'' (front page, March 11):    I am saddened to read that the troops returning from the most recent fighting in Afghanistan were ''jubilant'' and ''profanely triump...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Saying Battle Is Reaching End, U.S. Sends Troops Back to Base'' (front page, March 11): I am saddened to read that the troops returning from the most recent fighting in Afghanistan were ''jubilant'' and ''profanely triumphant.'' If we choose to engage in battle, the more appropriate response should be that of regret for what we perceive to be a necessary action.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Crain letter on Mar 11 front page article says it is incendiary to gloat over victories in Afghanistan

docs.snippet: Ari Fleischer was teased at the Gridiron dinner the other night for being ''the only White House press secretary with his own Middle East policy.''     That was because the president's spokesman had blurted out an incontrovertible truth last week,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ari Fleischer was teased at the Gridiron dinner the other night for being ''the only White House press secretary with his own Middle East policy.'' That was because the president's spokesman had blurted out an incontrovertible truth last week, as pressure mounted for renewed U.S. intercession between Palestinian attackers and Israeli defenders.
docs.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column says Ari Fleischer was right when he said that intense pressure for comprehensive Israeli-Palestinian settlement brought to bear two years ago by Pres Clinton is cause of current violence there; says then-Prime Min Ehud Barak, desperate to get re-elected, made egregious concessions of land, and Yasir Arafat, seeing Israel's panicked leader on run, was emboldened to make greater demands, to envision total victory, and to launch terror war on civilians; says Israel must now make plain that its population will be aggressively defended, while pursuing all openings to negotiation; calls on United States to demand that Arafat defeat other terrorist organizations, and to reject any linkage between present war in Israel and coming American war on Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq (M)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Tom Daschle and other elected officials in his party should be ashamed, given their comments about the conduct of the war on terrorism (''Democrats Starting to Fault President on the War's Future,'' front page, March 1).     It i...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Tom Daschle and other elected officials in his party should be ashamed, given their comments about the conduct of the war on terrorism (''Democrats Starting to Fault President on the War's Future,'' front page, March 1). It is understandable that the man in the street might confuse the success of this difficult military and diplomatic action with the capture of Osama bin Laden and others, but we should expect more from our elected officials. Mr. Daschle's behavior undermines this country's declared goal of defeating Al Qaeda and terrorism, regardless of their leaders.
docs.abstract: Geoffrey W Bramhall letter contends Sen Tom Daschle and other elected Democratic officials should be 'ashamed', given their comments about conduct of war on terrorism
